audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a female news anchor discussing her interview with John Stewart of the Daily Show, where he critiqued the 24-hour cable news world. She adds that the interview allowed her to get some stuff off her chest. This is followed by a conversation between a man and a woman, discussing how cable news is not perceived as very different from the Daily Show. The man then jokes, "I love that F-35," to which the woman responds, "That wasteful engine bit, that killed him." Another female news anchor transitions by stating, "That's ahead, please stay with us". The clip then cuts abruptly to sounds of a cash register, followed by a man speaking what sounds like a news report.

The clip begins with a male speaker expressing a viewpoint: "I always feel like, I don't care where it comes from, if it's right it's right," describing this as earned authority. A second, female speaker responds affirmatively with "Right," and inquires about handling misinformation in a polarized environment. The male speaker counters with "You cannot, you cannot control crazy."

The audio clip consists of a discussion between two speakers, a man and a woman. The woman mentions Iraq and Bush, referring to the Delfer Report and weapons of mass destruction. The man responds, questioning if Bush changed his rationale or simply started discussing other reasons for the war. He mentions "four rationales for the war," with the main one being fear, referencing Colin Powell and anthrax. The man points out that even in the Delfer Report, Saddam Hussein was trying to get around sanctions to reconstitute his weapons program, implying that the situation is not as straightforward. The woman appears to agree with the premise.

A male speaker introduces the topic of nuanced perspectives, saying, "when I look to the left, the left always says, 'we're not black and white.'" A female speaker interjects to ask for clarification. The male speaker continues, claiming the left criticized Bush for being "so black and white." He then questions if the left suffers from the same "myopia." The female speaker responds that "bad arguments exist everywhere" and states she dislikes bad arguments. She also says, "I'm trying to pursue bad arguments wherever I find them" and wants to clarify a point about Bush and WMDs. Immediately following this, a percussive sound occurs.

The clip features a conversation between a male and a female, focusing on political topics. The woman suggests that "Bush accepted that Saddam wasn't pursuing weapons of mass destruction" and changed his narrative. The male speaker expresses doubt, stating, "I don't know if...". She then continues, referencing "the report" and Saddam, while the man says it was "really sad" they didn't find anything. She mentions Saddam pursuing weapons of mass destruction and declares it to not be true. He counters that it's "true depending on where you start the pursuit." He then uses the analogy of his son's pursuit of a car to illustrate a point. He ends by acknowledging the manipulation and that it is.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing "narrative manipulation", suggesting that someone is dismissing a certain topic. A second, possibly also male, speaker jumps in, asserting that someone is intentionally using this tactic to make people believe the Iraq war was justified due to weapons of mass destruction. He then asks, rhetorically, if the world is safer, suggesting disagreement with the narrative. The speaking tone is serious and argumentative throughout.

The clip features a male speaker questioning a female speaker about the beliefs of someone else, specifically whether they thought "the world is safer without Saddam Hussein." The woman initially agrees, then disagrees because she doesn't believe "Saddam was pursuing weapons of mass destruction." The male speaker interjects to clarify that it's a matter of belief, stating he doesn't personally know the individual in question but believes they thought Saddam was dangerous. The male speaker suggests Saddam might have been waiting to resume his activities because they were being watched. This conversation is interrupted by an unclear sound, possibly related to moving or handling an object.
The audio clip features one male speaker passionately disagreeing with an idea, asserting that "one is truly dishonest and borderline evil." He then expresses a point of understanding.

The clip begins with a male speaker expressing his struggle to understand how someone who condones waterboarding can be perceived as not evil. He references Franklin D. Roosevelt's internment of Japanese Americans and questions whether he was evil. He states one must examine their own orthodoxy before feeling comfortable, emphasizing the need to fight on the most precise and proportional terms. The speaker's tone is reflective and searching.

The clip begins with a male voice saying "we can, okay if possible". Another female voice then asks "And?" The female voice mentions "waterboarding" and Bush's book, adding "He didn't just-". The male voice interrupts, saying "Is that what's next? Is that what happens now? Oh my god, what happens to me now?" The female voice continues to say that in Bush's book, he said "Damn right, waterboard the guy". She adds that it's hard for her to believe he did that, but he says that's what he did.

The audio clip begins with a female speaker, who notes that people arguing against torture "lost the argument" and it became an "asset." This is followed by a male speaker responding in a conversational tone, noting that he never got a "sense of shame," but more one of "legal maneuvering." He suggests they didn't think covering it up meant it was a bad idea or "paint them as evil," suggesting they didn't want to "get nailed for it." He finishes by indicating they needed to "figure out a way to do it."

A male speaker introduces a topic, posing a question about someone's intention to save American lives and whether that justifies certain actions. He raises further questions about where to draw the line, suggesting the hypothetical scenario of waterboarding everyone. He then narrows the discussion down, referencing gang violence in the city and proposing waterboarding gang members.

The clip begins with one male speaker discussing arguments, saying that if the starting point is "he's an evil man who did that to lie to us" he could take "gratuitous pleasure" in his "masculinity." A second female speaker chimes in to disagree. The male speaker acknowledges her point, then pivots to discussing how people take things and escalate them. The female speaker interrupts, stating that she doesn't think that she does that.

The clip opens with two people in conversation. A female voice emphasizes that they are "definitely part of the confictanator", but she believes that "criticism of George Bush on waterboarding is a precise criticism."  She thinks it is wrong to defend that action. A male voice responds that he does not get the sense that the argument is as passive, but he agrees that she has a fair point. The male voice believes the reality is somewhere in between, saying the argument has not been that this is wrong for the country, and suggests it was a little more. The female says "it's impassioned, certainly", adding "This is wrong for the country!" The male voice disagrees with the idea that it was just wrong for the country, but that instead it was that "you're a bad man." The woman says, that that isn't true. The male answers maybe. Finally, a female announcer says "that could very well be, he says". The announcer then says, "Or," laughing, "Yeah, there's more." She then asks the listener to stay with them for more of their interview.
